text: Chapter 17 is on applications of Constrained Least Squares. Uh, each of the applications in itself is like a huge field.
You can take whole courses, multiple courses on them. But it's just to show you, it's a- it's a very, very simple introduction.
And you can actually do something with Constrained Least Squares. So our first one is going to be on Portfolio Optimization in Finance.
Okay. So here's the- the setting is this is that we're gonna have- we're going to invest a total of V dollars.
V is positive in n different assets. So these could be different stocks, bonds, ETFs.
I mean, it- it actually doesn't matter what they are, uh, over some period. Um, could be a day, week, month.
I mean, this- this doesn't matter. Um, now, um, our investments,
uh, can include short positions. Now, a short position is essentially owning a negative amount of something.
And what it means is you borrow, uh, the asset, for example, uh, a share of Google stock,
I borrow it, um, sell it immediately so I receive cash. Um, but now, I have the obligation to repay, uh,
or to payback, to return one share of Google, uh, later, at some point.
So that's the- that's it. And it turns out that's- that's pretty much equivalent to owning a negative share of Google.
At first, it sounds strange and it is strange, but that- that's what it is. Okay. Now, um, we can describe our portfolio, um,
by a portfolio allocation weight vector w, and this is relatively common notation.
And what it does is w_i or w_j gives you the fraction of your total portfolio value that you hold in asset j.
And, uh, that means, for example, that capital V, that's your total portfolio value in dollars, um,
times w_j, that gives you the dollar value of how much you hold of asset j.
Okay. Now, um, well, by- by construction, w- 1 transpose w which is the sum of the weights is- is 1,
and that's- that's why there- why- that's why it's suppose to be a weight vector, right? It's something that adds up to 1. Now, they're not necessarily, uh,
non-negative, uh, the- the entries, they could be negative. Um, and when you see a negative one,
that simply means a- a short, uh, position. In fact, the- the term, uh, for a portfolio that doesn't contain, uh,
negative weights, uh, or short positions is long only because you can have a short position and a long position.
Long position means you actually own the thing. Um, and so a long-only portfolio is one where the w,
all the entries in w are non-negative. Okay. So here's a- a very specific example,
uh, with three assets, um, I have- my weight vector is minus 0.2, 0.0, 1.2.
Notice that the weights do sum up to 1. Okay. And what does this mean? Well, it means that we actually take a short position of 0.2 capital V,
that's in- in dollars, in asset 1. Uh, we don't hold any of asset 2, that's what the 0 means here.
And then in- in asset three, we hold 1.2 times our value. So- so roughly speaking,
what happened is we- we sold asset one that we don't even have, use the proceeds to buy more of asset three,
than, well, even then, the total value of our portfolio, right? So- uh, so that's kind of the idea.
Now, obviously, you would only have a portfolio like that if you thought for some reason,
um, you know, the first asset was gonna go down in value and the third asset was gonna go up.
Um, and the reason that- is pretty simple there, um, that if the first asset goes down in value, then later,
when I make good on my obligation to return the short position,
um, or close out the short position is how people would say it. Um, it's cheaper for me, so I've made money on that.
And if the third asset goes up, then when I sell it, I'm gonna do well.
So anyway, that's the basic idea. Okay. So, um, the- there's a concept of leverage.
Um, and actually, there's several different definitions of leverage, and as far as I can tell, all are used.
So and, you know, it just- it's no big deal, you just have to ask somebody when they say the leverages,
you know, to what they mean, which definition are they using? So, uh, here's the definition we'll use because it's simple,
it's the sum of the absolute values of the weights, okay? So that's- that's the idea.
Um, I mean, another definition that's quite common is our L minus 1 then divided by 2.
So, um, and you- and- and I think both are used. [NOISE] Um, now, you- you- I'll,
you know, henceforth, use our definition of leverage. Um, so capital L, the leverage is one when all the weights are non-negative.
Because when the weights are non-negative, the absolute values up here are actually equal to the w. You don't need the absolute values because they're all, uh, negative.
And then L is the sum of the w's, but that's 1. So- and that's- that's the smallest a leverage could be.
So that- that- that's a- that's a long only portfolio is tells you that the leverage is one.
Um, some people would say you're unleveraged, right? So leveraged generally means if it's bigger than 1,
it means at least one of the weights is- is less than 0. It means you hold a short position. And by leverage, what it means is you've pretty much,
you've sold some assets, whichever ones you're holding short, and use the proceeds to- to pile more money into other investments.
That's kind of the idea behind leveraging. Okay. Oh, another portfolio that comes up is the
so-called 1 over n portfolio or in our language, the ones over n portfolio.
And that's because it's also called the Uniform portfolio. And it's basically like, you know, yeah,
if- if you've got 10 assets, put 10% of the total value in all of them. That's it.
Okay. Um, now, another common assumption is that we'll often assume that asset n and some people use asset 1, doesn't matter.
Um, is risk free is the way people would say that. Um, and that's another way to say that people also say cash or treasury bills.
The idea being is that there's not- is that there's not much risk in treasury, uh, bills. Um, okay.
So that's, uh, that's like asset n is- it's- it's a special one, it's risk-free. Um, actually, it's kind of interesting.
It- at some point, all of these things starts sounding the same, that's very much like in regression or something when I'm building a model.
Um, and my first basis function is the 1s vector, right? Uh, so my first basis function is the constant function 1.
And so that one is special, it's a constant, and we'll see that that's kind of what this is as well.
Um, so with- with that assumption, w- if you have w equals e_n,
it says put all of your- 0 of your portfolio on assets 1 to n minus 1, and put 100% of your portfolio value on asset n. If asset n is cash,
then you'd say, well, that's the portfolio, it's in all cash, okay? So it's just some basis. Okay. Um.
Now, we'll talk about the return over a period. Um, so what we'll do is we'll let r Tilde_j.
Um, it's gonna be the return of asset j over the period.
Um, and it's- we'll define that as the fractional increase in the price or value,
um, and it's a decrease, uh, if it's- it it's- uh, if it's negative, right? If the return is negative, it means it decreased in value.
And it's often expressed as a percent like, you know, plus 1.1 or minus 2.3. So if you say the return was minus 2.3%,
it means that, you know, you- for every dollar you put in, uh, the value of the end of the period was whatever it would be.
So 97 point, uh- I guess, 97.7 cents. Okay, so that's- that's what that means.
Now, your portfolio value, uh, also changes, um, over- over the investment period,
and we're gonna call the, after investment period value of your portfolio V plus, um, and the,
uh- the- the initial portfolio as V. So V plus is- V plus minus V is the increase in value of your portfolio.
Now, it could be negative, right? Which means, you lost money, but- or lost value. Um, if- if, uh, but it's- that's what it is,
just simply the increase and I'm not saying it necessarily increases, but the- it's the increase in the,
uh, value of the portfolio. And I divide that by the initial value. And then, uh, that is the fractional increase in the value of the portfolio.
Um, that's called the portfolio return. And it turns out that is exactly simply r Tilde transpose w,
where r Tilde is the- is the fractional, uh- is the, uh, return, the vector that gives you the fractional returns of all the assets, right?
So there you go. It's just- in other words, we're back to Week 1 of the class, it's just an inner product. So if you have, you know,
the weights inner product in- taking the inner product of the weights with the fractional returns of the assets,
um- individual assets gives you the fractional increase in value or the return of the whole portfolio, just inner product.
Okay. Now, um, what happens is if you hold, uh, uh, a portfolio for T periods and the- and the returns over that periods are r_1, r_2,
r_3, and so on, um, then the value at the end of the period is this, uh,
it's- it's actually you take a- a product, uh, of- of- it's V_1 times 1 plus r_1 times 1 plus r_2,
you know, and so on. Uh, so that- that's- that's the actual, uh, value of the- of the portfolio, right?
So- and this is, you know, if I tell you, look, I put in a million dollars and then it goes up 5% of- then- then down 7,
then up 3, then up 6, then down 2, you know, that kind of thing. Then the value at the end is gonna look like that.
So- because you just do- you just- each time, you're just multiplying by 1 plus the return. Okay. And for some reason that's historical and that I don't know the origin of, uh,
portfolio values versus time, um, are- are traditionally plotted using,
uh, from an initial portfolio of $10,000. I- I don't know why. But I- it- it's- it's a number maybe from
the 60s, I'd have no idea what it is, but that's what it is. I mean, so you'll see that, but you'll see everything else. You'll see people start with a dollar or something.
And- and- and- and of course, if you- if you- it's linear in that amount, right?
So if I double the amount you put in initially, then the total value at the end is double that. So- okay. So in that sense it doesn't matter.
But just so you know, you're gonna see things that are referenced to $10,000 at the beginning and you might ask why and the answer is, well, two things.
Number 1, I don't know, and number 2, it's- it's historical, for sure. Okay. So, uh, this brings us to the return matrix.
So suppose, uh, we're going to hold a portfolio with weights W over T periods.
Okay. So this is the- the setting. Um, and we're going to define, uh, a- an asset return matrix,
which is gonna be T, uh, by n. So here's T, and n. I- I've- I've drawn it as if it's tall.
Uh, that's often the case, but not always, right? So we- we could- we could easily have- oh,
I should say that the asset- the group of all the assets you're investing in, I'll teach you some slang, is called the investment universe.
So n is the size of the universe of assets. And so it would be like- it would be the kinda things people would say, "What's your universe?"
And the person would come back and say, "I don't know, US, whatever, hi-cap , or I- who knows? That kind of thing." Anyway, there,
you know- you know- you know, another slang word. Okay. So all right. So we make this return matrix R. Um,
and it's T by n. Um, now, the rows, uh, correspond to periods,
time periods, and you know, a very common thing would be a day, right? But- but I mean, the- none of this, the math works.
If this is every one minute, if it's every week, quarter, year, it doesn't- really doesn't matter.
Um, but let's just- I'll continue talking, speaking as if, uh, we're talking about daily stuff.
Okay. So- so each row here, um, is gonna be- is actually the transpose of
the return vector over a period T. So those are the, uh- that's- that's the row.
So a row here would tell you, how did all the assets do on that particular day?
Okay. Now- now, column is super interesting. A column focuses on a single asset and it tells you the time series of its returns.
Okay. So that's what that is. Um, now, the portfolio return time series is simply- well,
it's matrix-vector multiplication. You multiply this matrix, um, by the weight vector w and you get Rw.
And that is- that's your- that's your- that's a time series. So r is a time series T long of the portfolio returns.
So if you look at it, it would say it would be minus 0.01 plus 0.02, minus, you know, 0.05, you know.
And that means it kinda, you know, went down a percent, then went up 2%, then down half a percent, that kinda thing.
Okay. Um, all right. So, um, if the- if the last asset is risk-free,
which we're going to assume, then the last column, uh, is the- that's the return series of that risk-free asset,
um, and what that is, it's very simple. It is simply Mu risk-free, which is a number, times 1s.
In other words, it's constant. So that's what it means to be risk-free. I mean, if you like, you can set ru- sorry, Mu, uh,
risk-free equal to- 1, you know, whatever. And then it just means it's like putting whatever,
uh, dollars, you know, under the mattress or something. It just nothing happens. But, uh, what it really means is it goes up.
And now, by the way, interest rates at the time, this is 2020, interest rates are like super low, so it might as well be 0 frankly.
But, uh, in- in any case, that's what- that- that's the idea is that- is that you get the interest rate on,
if it's daily, uh, you know, one day's interest, uh, which is extremely small right now. It's fine. Um, okay.
And that's called the risk-free per period interest rate. Uh, that's- and, you know, it makes perfect sense.
I mean, if you scan- well. First of all, the standard deviation of that column is 0 because it's constant.
And that's actually kind of- that's gonna be one of our definitions of risk, is, you know, how much does the return vary,
and that last column, it's zero, and that's why we call it risk-free. Now, you'll look if it has another column in there which is Tesla or Google,
or something like that, or you'll see it be positive, negative, positive, who knows what it is, right?
So varying all around. Um, and that's, of course, not risk-free.
Okay. So, um, so here I get- I mean, I'm gonna get a time series that's a vector of portfolio returns,
it depends on W. And we're gonna go into great detail about- about that later. But for right now, we just say depends on W- it's it's- it's- W's fixed.
It doesn't matter how you've gotten it, doesn't matter. Um, so- and- but once you fix w,
you get a time series of portfolio returns that- that's r here. I could plot it, I could do all sorts of stuff.
Now, the average return, or the- or people just say the return is the average of that.
So that's the average return. Um, and the risk is the standard deviation. So the standard deviation,
the risk of your portfolio says how variable is the portfolio return,
that's really bad- that's what the standard deviation measures. And so if it's 0,
uh, which would be the case if w equals en, that means put the entire portfolio into the risk-free thing,
then the risk is 0 because the portfolio- the return is Mu risk-free.
And the standard- the standard deviation is 0 because every single day, you- you are exactly Mu risk-free.
So, uh- so that's- that's what- that's- and that- that's what people, uh, call risk. Okay. Um, now, they're related to the increase in value,
uh, not directly- um not- not, it's not like it's equal to it, but here's the analysis.
It says, um, if you look at what is V_T plus 1, that- that's- that's what's the value of your portfolio,
you know, T- basically if you propagate forward T time steps from, uh- from- from one.
Right. Your initial timestep, and it's equal to this, it's V_1 and- and well, you remember, it's the initial value times and then you just simply
multiply by all the- the returns, right? Oh, by the way, some people refer to this process of multiplier- of-
of taking the product of 1 plus things as compounding, right? So it's- it's- it means kind of if you- if- if- if it- if you get- if you do well,
you- you re-invest, right? For us, that's kind of- that's what the weight vector means. Um, now, this, I'm gonna expand this now.
And the first term I get is when I multiply all the ones together in this big product here, um, and that's gonna give me V_1. Then I get V_1.
And the next term is when I get in all of these, I multiply- I take all of the ones, except one of them,
and then I take one of the r's, and that's gonna get me this- this term here. Now, what's missing?
I can tell you what I have neglected in that approximation. I've neglected all the terms where there's products, like,
you know, r_3 times r_7, and in fact, there's even like even bigger ones. The argument goes like this.
If r is on the order of like, you know, 1%, um, something, you know,
just roughly, right, if r is on the order of a percent or something, it's 0.01. And so this thing makes sense here.
Um, but when you multiply, you know, two quantities on the order of 0.01, you get something that's 10 to the minus 4 and it's basically negligible.
So, uh- okay. So that's the approximation being made here. And that says that your value at,
um- at- at, you know, if you go capital T, uh, periods in the future,
it's basically your initial value plus your initial value times this number, which is T times the average return, right?
So- so the basic idea is it tells you that the average return tells you something about the increase in portfolio valid- uh, value over that period.
And, you know, look, if the returns are ridiculous things like plus minus, you know, 0.15, 0.2,
then this is kind of a crappy approximation, but nevertheless, it's a- it's a good one for- in fact, for a lot of situations, it's actually a very good one.
Oh, and the only thing I should say about that is this tells you why you would want the return to be large.
I mean, it- look, it's kind of obvious way you'd want the return to be large. This quantifies it. It basically says it has to- it- it has to do with
an approximation that tells you about your, um, you- your increase in- in value over some period.
Okay, So, um, usually both risk and return for a financial, uh,
return time series are- are not quoted as- as, you know, per day or per week or per month,
or whatever you're doing. Um, they're all- er, they're all converted to what- what it would be over a year,
um, and that's called annualized. And that way it's easier, right? If I say what's the return on that- the indigo that's so bad, it's 15%.
What they mean is it's 15% over a year. Now, what's the risk on it? That's also given as 12% over a year.
Okay. Something like that. All right. So, um, so the way you do that, uh, is I'll- I'll- it- the annualized return, that's an easy calculation.
You simply multiply. If there's P periods per year, um, then you simply multiply it.
So if this is weekly that might be 52, right? If it's daily, there's about- let's see,
there's about 250, maybe closer to 252 trading days in a year. I mean, obviously it depends on
the market and all that kind of stuff so it can be more or less, I mean, it can be all sorts of stuff, but that's a P, it would be about 250 there.
It's a good approximation of it if it's daily trading. Um, the annualized risk is interesting.
You don't multiply by P. Uh, actually what you do is you take the standard devi- uh, sorry, the, uh,
the variance and you multiply- that you multiply by P. Standard
deviation is the square root of that and so you actually have to take the square root of P. Uh,
so it says that the annualized risk is the square root of P.  So that's about 16 or something like that if it's- if you have 250,
um, and it says if you had 250 trading days a year your annualized return, right?
Would be 250 times the average of the daily return, and your annualized risk would be square root 250.
And you know what? If it's not 250, it's 252 or 251. You know, go ahead and fix it. This is just to give you a rough idea of what it is.

it's w equals 1s over n. Uh, what- I mean, what should be w?
Right? Um, now we have two desiderata, so there's two things that we want here.
Um, the first is we want- we want high mean portfolio return and we want low portfolio risk,
so this is a bi-objective problem. I mean, immediately we can see that it's a- it's a problem involving,
we want the mean to be high and we want the risk to be low. Um, now, the tricky part like,
you know, I'm sure someone has said this. Um, [NOISE] the tricky part is, of course, you- you don't know what the returns are gonna be in the future.

you could do very well without this. Okay. Um, so we don't know that, but here's what we do know.
Um, we do know- we- we know let's say for example, last year's returns because it's- it's historical record, we can go look it up.
Um, so, of course, we don't know next year's returns, right? I- I- I should add, you know,
that's basically what happens if you walk into a hedge fund. That's basically what people are doing is they're trying to figure out what are- you know,
what are next year's returns? Uh, not just hedge funds. I mean, any kind of- any- any kind of people- a- anyone
putting together a portfolio is basically doing that. They're trying to figure out, you know, what's gonna happen to Tesla.
Might be in the next hour, might be in the- tomorrow or 10 days from now, and it might be, you know,
quarter by quarter. Um, okay. So- so we don't know the future basically,
um, but we do know the past. Um, and so here's the idea, uh, and it's this.
We're gonna to choose a weight vector that would have worked well on past returns. That's what we're gonna do [NOISE],
and this- n is a matter of faith, which is not always a well-founded or whatever.
Um, and we're simply going to hope that it is going to, uh, work well going forward.
So that is going to be the approach. Um, now it sounds weird, uh, and we'll get- we'll get to just how weird it is.
I do want to point out it's not, er, it's not- I mean, that's exactly what you want data fitting, right? If you do data fitting and someone says, what are you doing?
You'd say, well, I'm fitting a model and you go, well, what do you really want to do? Oh, well, I wanted to be able to predict- you know,
starting next week I wanted to be able to predict demand for my product, and they were like well, how are you doing?

it's not the demand next year. And you go, yeah, I know- I know. Anyway, so I'm just saying data fitting is very- is very similar, um,
and we'll get to what the essential- the essential assumption is something like that.
Yeah, but if- if the way demand varied last year is the same as how it

We want high return, which is the average of little r, um,
and we want low, uh, risk,um, and the risk is the standard deviation variance which is the square of that.

what would have been the best constant allocation had we known future returns?
